div.head: John Ashbrooke Will.
div.p:
In the name of God Amen. The last will and testament of John
Ashbrooke in Charles County being in perfect memory.
I give and bequeath my soule unto the Almighty God and my body to
be entered in the ground and in it to be desently buried as my dear wife
shall see to it.

2d I give and bequeath unto my loving wife one chow call by the name of
Juyne with a chow calf by her side now naming. I give unto my sonne James
one chow called by the name of fortune and two yearlings being heiffers
and come of the above said chow Juyne and all the land that at this
present belongs and dappertains unto me the sd. John onely my wife to enjoy
the sd. land for her life time provided she keeps herself unmaryed but
is that she should mary that the the said James shall tke the said land
into his possession and that my wife shall have nothing to do with it.

3d I give and bequeath unto my Daughter Keese one yoing heafer at two years
of age Called by the name of Gentle.

4 I give and bequeath unto my Daughter Elizabeth one three year olf heaffer
Called by the name of Ham.

5. I give and bequeath unto my Daughter Ann one heaffer called by the name of
Carmakin meat I desire that my sone James if I die shall be a free man and to
disperse of himself as hee shall see fit and likewise to have two gunns which are at
presentmy own but if I die to be at his dispersing meet for the house hold
my desire is that it shall remaine in the house for that good of them all
and no separation to be made as wainscoat I kept and a small loc that my
wife
wife put her in I give unto her.

Sixthly I constitute and appoint my loving wife to be to be Executor and to see
my will performed in all respects whatsoever as is above specified and to the
confination of which I have hereunto set my hand and seal the seventeenth
day of January in the year of our lord. 1677/8.

Signed Sealed & Delivered
In the presents of us
Hrt. Burghitt - Simon Stephens
John Ashbrooke

On the back of the aforegoing will was Endorsed the following probate & petition (to will)
January 24th day 1678. Then Simon Stephens being sworn upon the Evangatent
that he saw and heard John Ashbrooke deceased Sign Seal Deliver &
publish the within mentioned his Last will and testament.
John Stone

Maryland Jst. The Honorable Philip Colvert Esquire Chancellor and Chief Judge
on Comisary Gen. for probate of wlls and granting of administrations
